abstracts.cdata!:
Overall the National Agricultural
            Research Project is rated marginally unsatisfactory. Lessons
            learned follow: Legal advisers should be included in the
            project design when success depends on legal texts or
            statutes. A special procurement commission can help speed up
            procurement and disbursement, provided that it has an
            efficient administrative and financial management system.
            Conditions for effectiveness, if not fulfilled before
            project implementation, are unlikely to occur. Farmers
            participation in research projects improve the work's
            relevance, as well as the quantity and quality of results.
            Adequate bylaws for autonomous management of research staff
            by research institutions and sustainable financing
            mechanisms are necessary to provide minimum incentives and
            an enabling research environment. Collaboration with
            research institutions and networks should be built into or
            facilitated by research projects. The project design needs a
            mechanism to ensure the continuity of a common understanding
            of project objectives and performance indicators across time
            and project managers. Project management needs recruitment
            systems, results agreements, and incentive systems.
            Providing research with more autonomy and allowing separate
            governance and funding bodies, is likely to be more
            effective than the establishment of national governance
            bodies. To insure consistency, the SAR (or PAD) must be
            emphasized as a major supervision instrument.
